comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: This would have to be on the way down to the crossing over the Wollondilly River, which used to be the way to Yerranderie. All the valley visible in the right background is now covered by Lake Burragorang, the lake formed by Warragamba Dam.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
@Wardie44B,
Wonder if the road is still there albeit a no through road? Would you think that this is the road from near Camden/The Oaks or further South?

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: That is quite an impressive cut and fill excavation! maybe there is a natural shelf under the road?

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Yes, it is the road from Camden and The Oaks. I believe there is still a coal mine there but the public isn't allowed past the turnoff to Burragorang Lookout, which is back up over the top from this shot.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: I'd love to see the same scene today

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47572660@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] The exact location has been puzzling me for years. There seems to have been a new line of road in about 1900 avoiding this "famous zigzag" (as it was known in contemporary newspapers), and not quite so steep - probably the track marked as "Burragorang Rd" on this Google MapsSatelliteImage - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Burragorang+Road,+Nattai,+New+S... . As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47572660@N08] says above, the zigzag appears to be beneath the lookout. There seems to be a bit of a track discernible in the trees, though probably overgrown or washed away; hence few recent references to the stunning view. A Trove search produces several interesting newspaper articles ca.1900 talking about the zigzag. trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/result?q=burragorang+road+zigzag

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47572660@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] There is a better resolution satellite photo (dated Feb 2010) at www.nearmap.com/ . Just tick all the boxes for personal use etc. Nothing conclusive though ...
